subject.display: 45-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease due to diabetic nephropathy

encounter.display: Inpatient encounter for deceased-donor kidney transplantation, postoperative day 7 discharge

text.div: 45-year-old male presenting for hospital discharge on postoperative day 7 following uncomplicated deceased-donor kidney transplantation for end-stage renal disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy. He reports feeling well overall, with resolution of preoperative uremic symptoms including fatigue, pruritus, and anorexia. He denies incisional pain, fever, chills, dysuria, oliguria, edema, or shortness of breath, and confirms urine output of 2-3 liters per day. Vital signs are stable: blood pressure 128/76 mmHg, heart rate 82 bpm, temperature 36.8°C, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute. Physical exam shows a clean surgical wound without erythema or drainage; transplant kidney is nontender without bruit. Labs indicate stable renal function with creatinine 1.3 mg/dL and tacrolimus trough 8.2 ng/mL. He expresses mild anxiety about polypharmacy adherence but understands discharge instructions after education.

The patient is a 45-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension complicated by end-stage renal disease due to diabetic nephropathy, who underwent deceased-donor kidney transplantation seven days ago. He had been on hemodialysis for 18 months with progressive uremic symptoms that resolved promptly post-transplant. The procedure was performed via standard heterotopic approach in the right iliac fossa, with immediate graft function (brisk diuresis >2 liters in first 24 hours) and no intraoperative complications (cold ischemia 18 hours, warm ischemia <30 minutes).

Postoperatively, he spent 48 hours in the transplant ICU with stable vitals and no hypotension or arrhythmias. Immunosuppression followed KDIGO guidelines with basiliximab induction (20 mg intraoperatively and postoperative day 1), followed by tacrolimus (target trough 8-12 ng/mL), mycophenolate mofetil, and corticosteroids. Prophylaxis for opportunistic infections included valganciclovir and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, given CMV donor-positive/recipient-negative serologies. Hospital course was uncomplicated, without rejection, infection, or delayed graft function; creatinine reached nadir of 1.3 mg/dL by day 3, with resolution of acidosis and electrolytes. Mild incisional pain resolved by day 4 with acetaminophen; anemia (hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL) was managed with erythropoietin.

Transferred to the ward on day 5, he ambulated independently and tolerated a renal diet with insulin for glycemic control. He reports improved energy and mild anxiety about medications, addressed via education on adherence tools. Repeat labs on discharge confirm stability (creatinine 1.3 mg/dL, tacrolimus 8.2 ng/mL), supporting safe home transition with outpatient monitoring.

The patient is a 45-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, complicated by diabetic nephropathy leading to end-stage renal disease and mild retinopathy without vision loss. Pre-transplant diabetes management included insulin glargine and aspart (metformin discontinued due to low eGFR); HbA1c was 8.2%. He has a 20-year history of hypertension, controlled pre-transplant with lisinopril 20 mg daily (held perioperatively) and metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily.

He started hemodialysis 18 months ago via left upper extremity AV fistula (after failed peritoneal dialysis with two peritonitis episodes). Dialysis was adequate (Kt/V >1.2), with complications including anemia (epoetin alfa and iron), hyperparathyroidism (PTH 450 pg/mL, treated with calcitriol and sevelamer), and metabolic bone disease. Echocardiogram showed mild left ventricular hypertrophy (EF 55%). Surgical history includes AV fistula placement and two temporary catheters. No prior abdominal surgeries, malignancies, or autoimmune diseases. Allergies: penicillin (rash). Family history: maternal type 2 diabetes, paternal hypertension. Immunizations up-to-date, including hepatitis B.

Social history: Former smoker (quit 10 years ago, 5 pack-years), occasional alcohol, no illicit drugs; employed as an accountant, married with two children, urban residence with support.

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 128/76 mmHg (seated, right arm), heart rate 82 bpm (regular), respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, temperature 36.8°C orally, oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Weight 78 kg, height 172 cm, BMI 26.4 kg/m².

The patient is a well-appearing, alert 45-year-old male in no distress, with subtle anxiety noted during medication discussion. Normocephalic, atraumatic; moist oral mucosa; pupils equal and reactive; clear tympanic membranes. Neck supple without lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm, no murmurs; nondisplaced PMI. Lungs: Clear bilaterally, no wheezes. Abdomen: Soft, nontender with active bowel sounds; right lower quadrant incision (10 cm) clean, dry, well-approximated without erythema or drainage. Allograft palpable, nontender, with soft systolic bruit but no thrill.

Extremities: Warm, perfused with 1+ lower leg edema (improved from preoperative); brisk capillary refill, 2+ pulses bilaterally; mature AV fistula without thrill. Skin: Mild pallor, no jaundice or pruritus.

Neurologic: Nonfocal, 5/5 strength, intact sensation, steady gait. Exam supports uncomplicated recovery with stable graft.

Laboratory Results (Postoperative Day 7)

Renal: Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL (stable from nadir, preoperative 8.2 mg/dL), BUN 28 mg/dL, eGFR ~60 mL/min/1.73 m² (CKD-EPI). Electrolytes: Na 138 mEq/L, K 4.2 mEq/L, Cl 102 mEq/L, HCO3 24 mEq/L. Ca 9.2 mg/dL, PO4 3.8 mg/dL, PTH 320 pg/mL (down from 450 pg/mL).

Hematology: Hb 10.2 g/dL, Hct 31%, MCV 92 fL, WBC 7.8 x 10^3/μL, platelets 220 x 10^3/μL. Tacrolimus trough 8.2 ng/mL (target 8-12 ng/mL).

Metabolic: Glucose 128 mg/dL, HbA1c 8.2%. LFTs: AST 22 U/L, ALT 28 U/L, total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL, albumin 3.8 g/dL. Urinalysis: Clear, SG 1.015, pH 6.0, no protein, blood, or infection.

Diagnostic Studies

Renal ultrasound: Normal allograft size (10.5 cm), no hydronephrosis, RI 0.65, patent vessels. ECG: Normal sinus rhythm, no changes. CXR: No infiltrate or effusion.

Findings confirm stable graft function without complications, establishing posttransplant baselines per KDIGO guidelines.

45-year-old male status post deceased-donor kidney transplant on day 7, with immediate graft function and uncomplicated recovery. Uremic symptoms resolved; stable vitals, diuresis 2-3 L/day, creatinine 1.3 mg/dL (eGFR ~60 mL/min/1.73 m²), normalized electrolytes. Mild anemia (Hb 10.2 g/dL) from surgical loss and erythropoietin deficiency, managed with epoetin alfa.

Immunosuppression: Tacrolimus (trough 8.2 ng/mL), mycophenolate mofetil 1 g BID, prednisone 20 mg daily (post-basiliximab), per KDIGO to prevent rejection. CMV prophylaxis: Valganciclovir 450 mg daily, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS TIW (D+/R- serologies). Diabetes stable on insulin (glucose 128 mg/dL); hypertension on metoprolol (BP 128/76 mmHg). Improving hyperparathyroidism (PTH 320 pg/mL).

Mild adherence anxiety addressed via education. Exam and imaging show graft integrity. Optimized for discharge with good short-term prognosis if adherent; monitor for rejection/infection risks.

Discharge home on postoperative day 7 with immediate graft function.

Medications:

  • Immunosuppression: Tacrolimus 4 mg PO BID (target trough 8-12 ng/mL, weekly levels); mycophenolate mofetil 1 g PO BID; prednisone 20 mg PO daily (taper: 15 mg week 2, 10 mg week 4, 5 mg month 3+).
  • Prophylaxis: Valganciclovir 450 mg PO daily (3-6 months); trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS 1 tab PO TIW (6-12 months); aspirin 81 mg PO daily.
  • CV/DM: Metoprolol succinate 50 mg PO daily (target BP <130/80 mmHg); insulin glargine 20 units SQ nightly, aspart sliding scale; renal diet (low K <3000 mg/day, PO4 <800 mg/day).
  • Anemia/MBD: Epoetin alfa 8000 units SQ TIW; iron PO; calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO daily; sevelamer 800 mg PO with meals PRN.
  • Hold lisinopril; resume 10 mg daily in clinic if Cr <1.5 mg/dL.

Instructions:

  • Wound care: Daily inspection, clean with soap/water, dry dressing; avoid immersion until healed (~2 weeks); report erythema, drainage, fever >100.4°F.
  • Diet/Fluids: Renal-friendly, 2-2.5 L intake daily (>1.5 L output); avoid NSAIDs, grapefruit, supplements.
  • Adherence: Pill organizer, alarms; report red flags (fever, oliguria <500 mL/day, graft tenderness, fatigue) to ER.
  • Activity: Light ambulation, sedentary work; no heavy lifting >10 lbs for 4-6 weeks; no driving until off narcotics.

Education reinforced; patient understands, motivated for adherence. Follow-up: Transplant clinic 1 week (labs: CBC, CMP, tacrolimus, UA); nephrology 1 month (US if needed); endocrinology/primary care 2 weeks (DM optimization). Prescriptions, med list, contacts provided. Favorable prognosis with compliance, anticipating stable eGFR >50 mL/min/1.73 m².
